Policy.0: The Information Security Policy document defines baseline control measures, scope, enforcement, and responsibilities. It is approved by the director and reviewed yearly by ISSC and ISWG. It covers confidentiality, compliance expectations, and management review.
Policy.1: Roles and responsibilities are clearly defined for CEO, ISSC, ISWG, Operational Directors, IT Asset Managers, Managers, Users, and Executive responsibilities. Segregation of duties is emphasized. Responsibilities include resource allocation, policy enforcement, awareness, and review.
Policy.2: Segregation of duties is mandated to reduce risk of misuse. Where segregation is difficult, compensating controls like monitoring and audit trails are recommended. Management ensures segregation when assigning responsibilities.
Policy.3: Management is responsible for setting security objectives, aligning with business strategy, resource management, policy setting, training, review, implementation, and continuous security. ISSC and ISWG conduct reviews and approve changes. Disciplinary processes and termination procedures are defined.
Policy.4: The Business Continuity Plan and Incident Response Plan include contact details and procedures for notifying local authorities (e.g., police, fire department) in case of facility disasters or security incidents.
Policy.5: The Information Security Policy mandates that Reducate and group companies regularly receive security news from external vendors, forums, newsletters, and magazines to stay updated on latest security news and vulnerabilities.
Policy.6: Procedures are in place to acquire and circulate information about vulnerabilities and malware outbreaks. Subscriptions to vulnerability and virus notification mechanisms are maintained and circulated to responsible teams.
Policy.7: The Information Security Policy requires review of system development life cycle (SDLC) methodologies, documented SDLC policies, quality checks, change control, and segregation of development, test, and production environments. Code reviews and penetration testing are mandated.
Policy.8: IT Asset Managers are responsible for classifying, managing, and maintaining an updated inventory of information assets, including hardware and software. Physical inventory checks are performed annually.
Policy.9: Acceptable use policies are defined covering IT, email, internet, and mobile equipment usage. Users are responsible for security of their PCs and must not misuse company resources. Disciplinary actions are defined for misuse.
Policy.10: Procedures require return of company assets (laptops, mobile phones, peripherals) upon termination of employment. Documented processes are in place for asset return and termination.
Policy.11: Information classification schemes are established based on value, legal requirements, and handling caution. Asset owners classify and manage information assets accordingly.
Policy.12: Information must be labelled and handled according to classification schemes. Guidelines for labelling and handling are provided in appendices.
Policy.13: Electronic messaging and information transfer are controlled and protected according to classification. External electronic communications require prior approval. Incident response and communication plans are defined.
Policy.14: Access control policies are defined including user registration, de-registration, access restrictions, privileged access management, and periodic audits. Two-factor authentication is mandated where applicable.
Policy.15: Formal user registration and de-registration procedures are in place. Unique user IDs are assigned and managed. User access is controlled and audited.
Policy.16: Password policies are defined including complexity, change requirements, storage, and reset procedures. Secret authentication information is protected and managed securely.
Policy.17: Access rights are assigned based on business needs and security requirements. Privileged access is restricted and controlled. Access rights are revoked promptly upon termination or role change.
Policy.18: Supplier relationships are governed by contracts and SLAs including security requirements. Credentials and references of external service providers are verified. Access is authorized and limited. NDAs are signed. Contract management and periodic reviews are mandated.
Policy.19: Supplier agreements must be formalized through contracts including security clauses; risk assessments are performed before contract signing; contracts include scope, roles, SLAs, access control, incident handling, change management, audits, data protection.
Policy.20: Credentials of external service providers are verified; reference customer lists required; external providers made aware of security policies; access is authorized and limited; network connectivity with external providers controlled; key IT suppliers are maintained and reviewed annually.
Policy.21: Contract management includes allocation of responsible person for ongoing management; periodic reviews of supplier performance based on SLAs, quality, timeliness, compliance, and security posture; change management processes apply to supplier services.
Policy.22: Use of cloud services must be approved by IT-Manager and ISWG; access restricted per access control policies; cloud storage reviewed yearly for external sharing; encryption and secure protocols required for cloud applications.
Policy.23: Security incident management procedures established including monitoring, detection, analysis, reporting; IT Security function responsible; subscriptions to vulnerability notifications maintained; incident reporting and briefing to ISSC; CAPA forms used for analysis; emergency actions documented and reviewed.
Policy.24: Procedures for assessment and classification of information security events as incidents; IT Security function analyses and identifies causes; decisions on incident classification and response made by designated teams.
Policy.25: Incident response policy implemented; IT Security function manages response including containment, eradication, recovery; emergency actions documented and reviewed; communication plans defined.
Policy.26: Post-incident reviews conducted; CAPA forms used; yearly simulations recommended; lessons learned incorporated into ISMS; ISSC reviews incidents monthly.
Policy.27: Evidence collection procedures defined including audit trails, documentation of incident handling steps; evidence retained in issue tracking tools; communication to authorities as needed.
Policy.28: Business Continuity Plan defines management of incidents and recovery; Crisis Management Team and Support Team roles defined; communication and recovery plans in place; recovery time objectives established.
Policy.29: Disaster Recovery Plans for IT infrastructure and services defined; recovery managers appointed; resources and recovery time objectives specified; restoration and resumption steps documented; periodic review and testing required.
Policy.30: Legal, regulatory, contractual requirements identified and listed; compliance with GDPR and other laws ensured; contracts include relevant clauses; regular review and updates performed.
Policy.31: Procedures to ensure compliance with intellectual property rights including copyright, design rights, trade secrets; software licensing respected; inventory maintained.
Policy.32: Information disposal through secure means; shredding or overwriting of personnel information; media disposal policy with evidence retention; backups and storage secured.
Policy.33: Privacy and protection of PII ensured per relevant legislation; GDPR compliance; data incidents reported; processing agreements signed; data leaks process in place.
Policy.34: Annual internal and external ISO audits required; ISSC and ISWG review security organisation yearly; management reviews include security policy and ISMS changes.
Policy.35: Policies and standards established and enforced; disciplinary processes for non-compliance; management reviews; training and awareness programs; documented procedures and controls.
Policy.36: Operating procedures documented and maintained; changes authorized by management; procedures cover incident management, change management, backup, recovery, system restart, support contacts.
Policy.37: Background verification and competence checks performed on all candidates; includes CV checks, interviews, security tests, references, and certificates of conduct as applicable.
Policy.38: Section 2.1 Screening details background verification and competence checks for candidates; Section 2.4 Termination of employment and Section 2.5 Change of employment describe documented processes for termination and role changes; confidentiality and compliance responsibilities are defined in the Information Security Policy.
Policy.39: Section 2.2 mandates all employees and relevant contractors receive appropriate awareness, education, and training on organizational policies and procedures related to their job function; ongoing e-learning and training programs are referenced.
Policy.40: Section 2.3 states failure to comply with the Information Security Policy may result in disciplinary action including termination; Section 9.4 Non-Compliance reiterates disciplinary measures for policy violations.
Policy.41: Section 2.4 details removal of access rights and return of company assets on termination; Section 2.5 covers documented processes for role changes; access control and asset return are enforced.
Policy.42: Section 3.2 mandates all external service providers sign NDAs or equivalent confidentiality clauses; internal confidentiality is emphasized in the Confidentiality Statement and policy.
Policy.43: Section 6.9 Network Security Policy and Section 8 Mobile Computing address remote access controls, approval requirements, and security measures for teleworking; Business Continuity Plan supports home/cloud working arrangements.
Policy.44: Section 5.1.4 requires users to report security violations immediately; Section 6.5 Security incident management defines procedures for reporting and handling incidents; Incident Response Plan and Incident Log are established.
Policy.45: Section 7.6 Physical Access describes secured building access via card swipe, key locks, alarm systems, and controlled access to server racks; perimeter security measures and zoning are defined.
Policy.46: Section 7.6 Physical Access details card swipe systems, key control, visitor escorting, and emergency access procedures to control physical entry.
Policy.47: Section 7.6 Physical Access includes securing offices and server rooms with locked doors and controlled access; higher security levels can be implemented on request.
Policy.48: Section 7.6 mentions alarm systems with codes changed yearly; however, no explicit mention of CCTV or continuous monitoring is found.
Policy.49: Section 7.6.12 references use of local country regulations for protection against natural disasters and malicious attacks; Business Continuity Plan addresses disaster recovery but lacks detailed environmental controls.
Policy.50: Section 7.6 requires that visitors and uninducted staff be escorted in secure areas; access to server rooms is restricted to authorized personnel only.
Policy.51: Section 5.2.4 recommends clear desk policy, destruction of critical information, and regular internal audits to ensure compliance.
Policy.52: Section 6.11 Asset Management requires inventory and physical location tracking; Section 7.6 mentions secured racks but lacks detailed equipment siting and protection controls.
Policy.53: Section 4.2 Equipment usage and Section 6.10 End-point Security Policy address controls for company assets used off-premises including return procedures and security requirements.
Policy.54: Section 6.8 Backup & Restoration Policy and Section 6.10 Storage devices define secure storage, disposal, and handling of storage media including encryption and destruction.
Policy.55: Section 6.9.36 mandates uninterruptible power supply (UPS) for network devices; Business Continuity Plan includes facilities and infrastructure recovery.
Policy.56: Section 6.9.37 requires cabling to be installed and secured per local or European regulations.
Policy.57: Section 6.9.38 states that any devices in the network perimeter should have regular maintenance and software updates as required or recommended by the supplier.
Policy.58: Section 6.8.8 details media disposal procedures ensuring data recovery is not possible, including physical destruction and retention of evidence. Section 6.11.5 states employees are not allowed to dispose of hardware/software without formal approval.
Policy.59: Section 2.1.2 Equipment usage defines documented procedures for borrowing company laptops and devices, and Section 6.10 End-point Security Policy covers controls on mobile devices, software installation, patching, and usage restrictions.
Policy.60: Section 5.3 Management of privileged access rights restricts assignment of privileged rights via formal authorization, minimum necessary rights, and separation of privileged IDs from regular IDs.
Policy.61: Section 5.2 Information access restriction enforces access control on a need-to-know basis aligned with business requirements and classification. Appendix 7.4 User Access Management formalizes access control procedures.
Policy.62: Section 8.1.8 states access control should be implemented to restrict access to the program source library. Section 8.1.17 requires development code stored in secure repositories enforcing access control and segregation of duties.
Policy.63: Section 4.1 mandates password confidentiality, complexity, and secure storage. Section 7.1 and 7.3 detail user authentication, unique IDs, password policies including length, complexity, change frequency, and two-factor authentication (7.2.2).
Policy.64: Section 3.3.1 in Business Continuity Plan and Section 3.3.2 in Business Partnership Contracts address capacity utilization monitoring and planning. Section 6.9.7 and 6.9.35 discuss network and system capacity monitoring and backups.
Policy.65: Section 6.1 and 6.6 detail malware protection including prohibition of unauthorized software, installation and updating of antivirus, real-time scanning, and virus incident handling procedures.
Policy.66: Section 6.2 defines a vulnerability management process including acquisition of vulnerability info, identification, evaluation, testing, and deployment of patches with approval and documentation.
Policy.67: Section 6.3 requires documented design and configuration of key IT systems, annual review and updates of configuration documents, and change management controls.
Policy.68: Section 9.3 Information Disposal mandates secure disposal of personnel information by shredding or irretrievable overwriting. Section 6.8.8 covers media disposal ensuring data recovery is impossible with evidence retained.
Policy.69: Section 8.1.10 mentions use of anonymised or pseudonymised data in testing environments to avoid use of production or personal data.
Policy.70: Section 4.1.3 mentions yearly review of files shared externally and cleanup procedures to prevent data leakage. Section 5.1.4 restricts unauthorized file sharing and mandates use of approved directories.
Policy.71: Section 6.8 Backup & Restoration Policy mandates periodic backups, documented procedures, secure storage, off-site backups, testing, retention periods, and disposal controls.
Policy.72: Business Continuity Plan defines recovery time objectives and alternative sites for critical activities, implying redundancy. However, explicit technical redundancy controls for information processing facilities are not detailed.
Policy.73: Section 6.14 Logging and Audit Policy mandates synchronized clocks, logging of all access, secure storage and backup of logs, and restrictions on sensitive data in logs.
Policy.74: Section 9.1 Responsibilities and procedures define management procedures for monitoring, detecting, analyzing, reporting, and handling information security incidents.
Policy.75: All computing systems managed must synchronise time with a central time server to ensure accuracy of audit logs.
Policy.76: Privileged utility programs or software should be approved by the IT department or system administrator; laptops/desktops have no admin privileges enabled.
Policy.77: Users may not load any software not provided by the IT department; only licensed software owned by the company is allowed; unauthorized software is prohibited.
Policy.78: Network security is maintained by firewalls, access control, logging, encryption for public networks, and regular patching of network devices.
Policy.79: Network services are secured by firewall rules, access restrictions, logging, and patch management.
Policy.80: Logical separation of networks is enforced with firewalls to prevent unauthorized access from public or wireless networks.
Policy.81: Web filtering or URL filtering is implemented on firewalls, routers, or switches to block web traffic and protect against threats.
Policy.82: Encryption is used for HDDs (Bitlocker, Filevault, Ecryptfs), VPN connections (IPSec with 3DES or AES-256), wireless networks (WPA/WPA2), and cloud applications (TLS 1.2+). Annual TLS testing is performed.
Policy.83: SDLC policies and procedures are documented; external providers' SDLC reviewed; quality checks and periodic reviews are performed; security requirements identified early.
Policy.84: Security requirements are identified and agreed prior to development; audit trails and access controls are implemented; privacy and encryption are incorporated in applications.
Policy.85: System hardening and minimal package installation are mentioned for Unix systems; IP restrictions and removal of unnecessary services are applied.
Policy.86: Code is reviewed by skilled personnel other than the author; secure coding guidelines are followed; code stored in secure repositories with access control and versioning.
Policy.87: Application security testing is performed manually and automatically; PEN-tests are conducted annually or after significant changes; acceptance criteria and testing are documented.
Policy.88: Outsourced development requires review of SDLC methodology; contracts must address licensing, code ownership, IP rights; security policy compliance clauses included.
Policy.89: Development, test, and production environments are separated with no shared components; access to development and test systems is restricted.
Policy.90: Change management is documented with strict review, approval, and closure controls; all changes including emergency changes are documented and approved; configuration management is maintained.
Policy.91: Test environments use limited, anonymised or masked data; production data is never used for testing; test data is removed before production deployment.
Policy.92: Audit and logging policies exist; incident management and security controls are in place; however, explicit controls for protecting systems during audit testing are not detailed.
